video.title: Getting first React job without experience - Ask Preethi
video.description:
Question:
I am really keen on getting some React JS experience but anywhere I apply to, they seek an experienced React engineer. I have learn React on my own and recruiters do not seem to appreciate it. Further, at this stage at the big companies, I reach 1-2 rounds behind the final round and then they say they found a more experienced person for the role. Recently I got a rejection from the [COMPANY X] and [COMPANY Y . These both required 5-6 years of industry experience. My application took me to the initial rounds and they seemed interested in gauging my potential - only to find I was not as good as somebody they were looking for.
Next week I am appearing for a full stack role at [COMPANY Z] but it is clearly out of my league - they are seeking at least 6 years experience in JavaScript. I am pursuing it for interview experience + what if it works out somehow?
I do not know many people who can refer me. How do I get my first React job [without any industry experience]?

Answer:
[See video]

About Preethi:
Preethi Kasireddy is an engineer based in San Francisco. She's an avid learner who taught herself programming and machine learning, and is passionate about understanding things clearly and explaining them to others via blog posts.

She was previously a front-end & API engineer at Coinbase, a digital currency platform, where she helped architect and rebuild their front-end in React, Mobx and Redux. Prior to that, she was a partner at the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz and an Investment Banker at Goldman Sachs. She studied Systems Engineering at USC.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/iam_preethi

-
Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: Tim Su
topLevelComment.text: She's too beautiful to be a developer of any kind.

topLevelComment.author: Kaviarasan velayutham
topLevelComment.text: Reddy garu. Please make this video crisp please. Don't waste our time. Thank you. From India...

topLevelComment.author: Brian Babu
topLevelComment.text: Good on you for taking action and sharing that knowledge with others because most people would have taken the “it’s because of patriarchy that I don’t have a job” predicament. Hats off!!

topLevelComment.author: Siddharth Sharma
topLevelComment.text: It's 3 years late but the concept is same. You are thinking too much as an applicant. You get hold of book, videos and some github examples. Learn React for a month. Then put a whole application in your resume for 5 years. Everyone else also is faking it. Nobody can put up with React for 5 years. You need to see the amount of garbage that coders put in the code. Everyone wants experienced person. But there were not so many react jobs before. So there could only be very few experienced people for all the experienced positions which have been filled in.

topLevelComment.author: Coogol
topLevelComment.text: Job requirements are just a rough guideline. As a developer you need to understand how to pass coding interviews. There are a lot of materials for that.  You can always land a job at a less competitive company. The money is usually the same as major tech companies.

replies.author: haha
replies.text: No way the money is the same. Some of the less competitive company's shares mean nothing more than paper. At major tech companies, you can get hundreds of thousand even a million worth of shares within a timeframe.

topLevelComment.author: Allisa Mint
topLevelComment.text: Remember that job specs are often written by morons in HR. They just pull a bunch of tech sounding terms out of their rears and post it as a job offer, often without even speaking to those working there as to the actual needs. I remember having a good laugh when leaving an IT position that I had done for the previous 5 years and seeing the posting put up for my replacement. I had NO idea what the posting was even talking about.

topLevelComment.author: Al Darfco
topLevelComment.text:
Don't get discouraged by postings from big corps. Many of them of postings are fake and used for internal reasons and for political reasons such as labor reporting or campaigns to bring in HB1 visa people that can be easily exploited or to justify outsourcing. My suggestion to anyone trying to break into the software industry is to become involved with your local university. There are many entry jobs there for people as assistants and interns. Open sourced project involvements are another excellent idea.

The other off-topic recommendation is to get involved with ending the Federal Reserve and hanging the banksters and bringing back an honest money system back to the USA. The trillions that the parasitic banksters have leeched and stolen over the last hundred years should be in YOUR pocket. So get involved in the efforts to exterminate the banksters and bring prosperity back to you, your family, community and the nation.

topLevelComment.author: Dave CJ
topLevelComment.text: The easiest way for people without any prior corporate experience is to start working on freelance portals like Fiverr, Freelancer, UpWork, PeoplePerHour...etc. Once you have at least 5-6 order fulfilled and having good reviews on your profiles, you can easily go to the employers requiring 1 year of experience, show them your portfolio that you've build using freelance projects and there are ample chances that they will prefer you after reviewing your LIVE PROJECTS.

topLevelComment.author: FlippantFishTaco
topLevelComment.text: The requirements listed in the job descriptions are often a front. Even jobs which include a degree in the requirements can be gotten without having a degree, in many cases. It's really just about whether you can do the job the employer has in mind for your chosen position, and conveying it during your interview.

topLevelComment.author: Travis Dukkovski
topLevelComment.text: I'm 48 and have been trying for 18 years to finally get a decent job as a programmer. I think my bad luck is because I am not pretty like you. I'm an INTP, so I am perfect (the best) for software engineering...but it seems a super cool personality matters way more. IDK what to do. I finally have a chance (working for room and board only) to start developing projects using Java (or even Scala). Anyone have tips for me? Give up?

replies.author: Jonathan Parker
replies.text:
Have you been continually investing in learning for 18 years? It's often hard if you don't get a chance to learn at work. Hence the reason why a lot of people say you need the passion. The passion translates into interest and time being invested outside of work hours. If you do that then you'll get a good job based on what you know, not what you've been doing in your day job because the people interviewing you will understand that some jobs are restrictive and they will give you a chance to get experience doing things the right way.
It's hard. I've been a developer for 10+ years and not yet got a dream job. Possibly I've not invested enough time outside of work.

topLevelComment.text: Apply for contract/freelancer jobs to start with. Companies are more flexible as if they don't like you - you're out the door the next day and they haven't lost much. No long notice/probation period etc for them!

I can learn whatever the job needs once they hire me, I just need to prove to them that I am worth hiring.

topLevelComment.author: Albert Cardona II
topLevelComment.text: Awesome video. I have been told by many people that work in software API documents to learn how to do things logically and then learn the syntax of a language. I don't understand how to do this properly what would be the best approach? I been in and out of web designing for a while but because I had been in and out of different countries or in training when I was in the military. Now that I am retired and don't have a job I would love to start pursing something I dreamed about doing for a long time. What would be the best advise about coding in general, should I be trying to code everyday?

replies.author: Keith
replies.text:
Hello Albert, I'm Keith from france. I can feel your struggle as i have been going through the same phase for years. I found in coding salvation to finally be able to get back on track and follow my dream, wich is to become an engineer. So here are some advice i use every day to get better at coding and anything else. 

It might look daunting at first, but it actually avoid the abysmal and endless search for material and guidance and hours of aimlessly searching for the wrong things, so try to bare with this and you'll succed.

Step 1. First, you need guidance and/or a good overview of your goal. If you have someone close that has the job you would like, this person would be the best starting point. If not, you need to research, based on your goal, the industry you wanna work in and the needs of this industry. For me, i'm going from software engineering to, later on, add electrical engineering (from software to hardware...yeah you guessed it, i wanna build Jarvis and then an iron-man!). so my closest target is "how to be a software engineer". 

Step 2. I then layed out a plan to become a good "full stack" software engineer using my own definition of "full" stack. Because full stack is the closest thing to having a good grasp of the maximum of software skills before going to hardware skills. This plan you can write on paper, excel sheets or anything really, you just need to implement it every now and of course be sure to always come back to it each time you progress to refresh your goals or situation. It does not need to be thorough. you can just write the skills you really need or want. 
Like "front dev = html and css = 3 months / back dev = Javascript + php + symphony2 = 6 months / full stack = add java EE for android and or iOS swift = 2 months".  

Step 3. Then, research the places to learn online that works best for you, both learning wise and money wise. There are tons of learning platforms now and you can learn anything through tutorials on youtube too. Prices can go from free (freecodecamp.com) to around 300 a month for a full degree with a recognized certification. If you are in usa, you probably have access for free to Lynda.com through your municipal library. Just get a card.

Step 4. Stick to 1~4 of these plateform. sometimes you don't understand well on one, for any reason, then hop on the second platform and maybee you'll have that click. It is important to not get stuck and drive yourself crazy on one particular point. Best way to get unstuck is by having a different point of view for the same thing. If you do understand but feel there is a gap in your ability to use said knowledge, then multiply projects involving said skill.
For exemple, i did not understand at all Bootstrap on codeacademy, but it got very clear on codeschool! And as of now, though i finally understand everything about bootstrap, i feel a huge gap when i want to use jquery with it. So i am currently doing lots of side projects to increase usage of jquery and slowly get more efficient using it. This is probably the best way for anyone to progress. Know when there is a lack of clarity on the teacher side and when there is a lack of experience (usage) on your side. 

Step 5. The universal learning skill. No gimmicks, no tricks. To learn and progress efficiently, after you have set a goal, is just to cut everything in very tiny bits. doesn't matter the time it takes, little chunks you do everyday will always trump big whole chunks you do once a month. It will also stuck much better in your long term memory and after a while, if you implement it right, it becomes more than a habit, it becomes a game you absolutely need to play to get better and break your own records! 
You don't need to code every day, you only need to get involved with code every day. That means, if you are lazy today, it's okay, just rest, but take ten to thirty minutes to enjoy a video with this guy https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AaGK-fj-BAM 
You don't need to strugle bro, enjoy coding. 

Step 6. When you feel confident enough, give back !  you can write a blog like Preethi, help a project on github or help an association for free...or you can just go to a club or any event involving code near you. It's a great way to make friends, get mentors, networking, have fun with fellow coder, sometimes get free food and at least learn something new or see it through more experienced people's eyes. 

That's it, hope it helps and get you through the day. good luck man and thanks for your service.
